Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Power Husbanding via Architectural Techniques (PHAT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Power consumption has become a dominant design constraint for computer systems. The ITRS Roadmap states: "power management is now the primary issue across most application segments." Worst-case power provisioning has given way to power capping, which throttles performance when necessary. Unfortunately, power-capping is analogous to brown-outs, which penalize all customers of an electrical utility, rather than those who can best tolerate loss of power. The thesis of this research is that computer systems should treat power as a precious resource to be husbanded: To direct and manage with frugality; to use or employ to good purpose and the best advantage. The research will investigate effective power husbanding via architectural techniques that appropriately shift power between different hardware components, much as good budgeting applies money where it is most effective. Power husbanding solutions include (a) low-overhead online mechanisms to estimate resource use, (b) low-cost techniques for dynamically changing a resource's operational level, and (c) effective policies for reaching power efficient operating configurations. Research will extend previous accomplishments on reconfigurable caches to enable online control at fine granularities, extend previous and develop new core architectures to enable proportional scaling of performance and power, and adapt and develop new memory systems which often accounting for 30% of system power.

Power husbanding seeks to make computation more power efficient, which has important national and global implications. The PIs will continue to advance the state-of-the-art through students, courses, talks, industrial affiliates, commercial influence, and open-source simulation infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Power consumption has become a dominant design constraint for computer systems ranging from cell phones to supercomputers. The 2007 International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors—industry’s consensus projection—states: “power management is now the primary issue across most application segments.” Power management shares many of the same issues as good household financial management: it is important to establish a budget that prioritizes how to best use limited resources yet is flexible enough to adapt to rapidly changing conditions. To address these issues, our research treats power as a precious resource to be husbanded: To direct and manage with frugality; to use or employ to good purpose and the best advantage.

This project had three main central thrusts. The first was to develop computer hardware components that allow tradeoffs between performance and power consumption, similar to the trade off between how fast we drive our car and its resulting fuel economy. The second was to develop mathematical models to predict the relationships between performance and power consumption, analogous to predicting miles-per-gallon for different driving speeds and road conditions. And the third was to develop policies to help determine the best allocation of limited resources, just as individuals must choose whether to drive fast (consuming more fuel) in order to have more time to work or play at their destination.

Specific outcomes include models and mechanisms for optimizing the power and performance of the processor, cache memory hierarchy, and virtual memory translation hardware. The project also played a leading role in developing the open-source gem5 simulation package (http://gem5.org), that is now widely used in industry and academia.
